context: Concerns have been expressed that toxic chemicals derived from tire rubber could be transferred to the environment and to organisms having direct contact with recycled products, tire wear particles or illegal dumps. For example, chemical additives such as Zn and PAHs were widely detected in the leachate from tire rubber (Stephensen et al., 2003; Wik and Dave, 2005; Zhang et al., 2008; Kanematsu et al., 2009). Zhang et al. (2008) reported that the levels of PAHs and Zn in CRM used as infill for artificial turf were above health-based soil standards, and lead in the CRM was highly bioaccessible in synthetic gastric fluid at relatively low levels (Zhang et al., 2008). Benzothiazole (BT) and its derivatives, derived primarily from tire wear particles, were detected ubiquitously in environmental samples (Reddy and Quinn, 1997; Kumata et al., 2000; Kloepfer et al., 2005; Ni et al., 2008). Indeed, this class of compounds has been cited as a tracer for street run-off in highly urbanized environments (Kumata et al., 2002). Most previous work has focused on the toxic chemicals in the leachate of tire rubber material. Wik and Dave (2009) reviewed thoroughly the ecotoxicological effects of tire rubber leachate and indicated its potential risks to aquatic organisms in water and sediment (Wik and Dave, 2009).

llm_generation.summary: In this context, 1,3-Benzothiazole and benzothiazole are both mentioned as chemical compounds derived from tire wear particles, which are detected in environmental samples. While benzothiazole is noted as a ubiquitous compound in the environment, 1,3-Benzothiazole is not specifically discussed in terms of its relationship to benzothiazole or its environmental impact. The mention of both compounds suggests a general connection through their origin from tire materials, but no direct interaction or comparative analysis is provided.
